text: Patient: So it seems to me though that - Doctor: Yeah? Patient: I come off the Xtandi now; I’m not having, I’m not taking anything to treat the cancer. Doctor: Yeah, right, until you get to the next one, which is this radium or Xofigo. It starts with another “X” name. So don’t get confused. So it’s not Xtandi; it’s Xofigo. Patient: But it would seem to me it makes more sense to keep taking Xtandi till I’m on that treatment. Doctor: You would think so but your cancer has figured it out. (pause) Family Member: So could it start like the first of January and then - Doctor: I mean you could, you know, you could make an arbitrary date like, okay, stop here, but I think you’ll feel better off the medicine that isn’t helping you anymore at this moment. Time to let it go. Patient: What was my PSA? Doctor: Is it back? Healthcare Professional: I don’t know that it is. Doctor: Oh from last time? Healthcare Professional: No, He did it the other day; no, he did it when he did his scans. He did it when he did is scans.

text: Family Member: The radium since it’s an injection is it IV injection or just a shot? Doctor: It is. No, they put a little IV in and then they kind of push it in over a minute and then you’re good for the month. Now, technically that’s liquid radiation so you’re kind of glowy. Patient: Ah. Okay. Doctor: So, do I advise that you go to the airport or to the Canadian border right after? No. Patient: No, that would not. Doctor: that’s not a good idea, no, no. But, you know, within a matter of like a few days it’s out. Now, its reasonably compared to all the other radiopharmaceuticals, easier to clean up. So, for example, if, and just for the record it’s like a fifteen thousand dollar vial. If you are oops and it lands on the floor, you don’t have to evacuate the building. Actually, what you do is you just put a piece of paper on there and then it’s protected. So, the half-life is really short but because it’s swirling in you as a human and then it stays in your bone which is why it’s only in the bone because it only goes to bone, um you will glow a smidge. So, we don’t want you to have like a newborn held up to you because you still will emit some sort of radiation. Patient: Okay, Alright. Family Member: Just for the first few days? Doctor: Yeah, they’ll give you like a set time. Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah, and same thing, you know, when you go to the bathroom. It’s the same thing because he doesn’t want to nail you just because you’re sitting next to him it shouldn’t be but, you know, for the younger people or people who are more immunocompromised who are older they get at risk for stuff and we say why bother. Family Member: They won’t put a port in him will they? Doctor: No, we shouldn’t have to. We shouldn’t have to. Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal?

text: Patient: Oh, my God! Wow Doctor: But I didn’t know it was my patient because rightly so they didn’t allow him to call from his cellphone. Patient: That makes sense. Doctor: So they had to call from the border. Oh, man! So then I was like oh, my gosh, then I was like well, how do I know you are who you say you are so I gave it right back to him and I go so, you know, what’s your phone number so just to be safe I called the guy back. I was like I don’t know who this person is, you know, it might be… Patient: Right, that’s a good point. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah and then, you know, there he was. Patient: Wow, wow. Doctor: So, then the next day when, you know, it was Monday afternoon my patient called and he goes okay, we’re never gonna do that again. I’m like, because he got his dose like Friday Patient: Right. Doctor: and then he traveled Sunday and I was like okay, that will teach you not to do that. So, now, I reported that back so now every single time, and they didn’t give him the card because they’re like it’s so low you won’t Patient: You won’t know yeah. Doctor: set off anything, you’ll be fine. After that incident, everybody gets a card. That’s a longwinded way of saying, everybody gets a card.

text: Patient: Well, that’s what I didn’t know was - Doctor: You know, and what raised my bar of suspicion is how much of this adrenal mass grew. Doctor: If the same kind of growth is happening in the bones, then you know it sort of took off all of a sudden, frankly. Family Member: Uh hum, right. Doctor: That made me think maybe the rest of your pain, also this big pain flare-up that you’re experiencing might be problematic Patient: Well see that’s - Doctor: But bone disease is always very hard to see. text: Healthcare Professional: Sorry, excuse me. Doctor: So um…just want to go over what's going on and sort of your scan results. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Let me ask first what your questions are. And then I can give you some thoughts. Patient: My question would be what are your thoughts about it? I mean, when you and I talked, we were kind of like, well, let's take the scans and see what comes up. We didn't necessarily think anything would because it's so small the numbers that we're reading right now. Doctor: Yeah, I still believe that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: My sense is that this really was a new baseline just to make sure we're, you know, again, it's unusual for this to be real. Patient: Right. Doctor: But it's a possibility. I mean I just had a patient just before you his PSA was point three, something showed up, we put a biopsy and guess what it was prostate cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but that's not the norm. It doesn't make sense. And yet that's an example where it shows possibility.

text: Patient: This will be done here? Doctor: Those – a lot of those intense monitoring and everything has to be done downtown. Family Member: But is it K__ or is it H____? Doctor: K__. Gradually we can switch you back to here. Once those intense periods are done, the whatever you know close monitoring is done, then I would switch you back to coming here and getting the medication dispensed. Patient: Does is require an IV or anything like that? Doctor: It will. They’ll probably start an IV just to have it for blood draws. Family Member: But then that means they won’t prick you every time for the blood draw. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I stay all day downtown or midtown? Family Member: And why are they, why do they, that’s interesting. Doctor: Well because they want to see how the levels of the drug, how long it takes for it to clear and things like that. So frankly along with the Xtandi there are not – this is sort of the first study of combining it with either Xtandi or Zytega and you know the single agent studies they kind of have they know what to expect. Family Member: Yeah.

text: Patient: The body reacts- Family Member: Why would it do that? Doctor: Uh, because basically the medicine is, uh, a protein your body makes and just fools the brain into thinking that there’s too much testosterone, uh, and sort of tells the testicles, “Stop making testosterone.” But that which is there gets released. Family Member: Ahhh. Doctor: And so you just get a surge. And so, Family Member: Ahh. Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. text: Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the – Doctor: Both ipilimumab and nivolumab. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: Big words. Patient: Who makes these things up? text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m not exactly sure when that will happen. But it accelerates and that happens sooner. Patient: Uh huh. text: Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Uhm and you’re in remission unless it recurs, comes back. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Last question, or uh maybe not. Mistletoe. I’ve had some friends that have said maybe that can help with side effects, things of that nature. If I were to research that, would that in any way – Doctor: Yeah, well thanks for asking that, so mistletoe is contraindicated certainly during chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it interferes with chem. I would say also during radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The reason is so you know everybody wants to be helpful and you know give you all kinds of natural products and things like mistletoe or kabuki mushrooms or whatever. The problem is that a lot of them are antioxidants. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So they’re really good stuff, except when you’re trying to kill bad things, and then they interfere because one of the things we’re trying to do in chemo is make reactive oxygen species which kill, make the DNA not work and breaks up and then the cells break up. If you give a medicine like mistletoe to interfere with the creation of those uh you know, what’s basically hydrogen peroxide that kills ah the cells, then you’re interfering with chemotherapy and radiation therapies. Family Member: The effectiveness of the chemo Patient: So that would be something . Uh nutrition – Then I’m scheduled to speak with someone from a company out of Colorado called

text: Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time- Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: I thought that was concentrating on that bundle that was in the lumbar region. Doctor: Yep. It was. Patient: It wasn’t, it wasn’t throughout where I have cancer throughout the spine. Doctor: Well, it’s, it’s, kind of altogether. You know? So it’s the lumbar, it’s the lower lumbar is where your- Patient: Radiation treatment was.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
